Concerning the Tantra Requested by the Four Goddesses, its commentary[61] states that it is the later tantra of a tantra called Supreme of All Secrets[62] in one thousand verses. The commentary to the Vajra Garland states that there is a twelve-thousand-verse Vajra Garland and a condensed Vajra Garland and that the Vajra Wisdom Compendium also has an extensive and a short form.[63] [17] In a citation above it was explained that there exists a Vajra Garland in three hundred thousand verses. The Explanation of the Intention is an explanatory tantra up to the twelfth chapter of the Root Tantra, but the remaining chapters were not translated.
gnyis pa [bshad pa'i rgyud kyis ji ltar bshad pa'i tshul bstan pa] la gnyis/
The teachings of the explanatory tantras
rgyud phyi ma dang dgongs pa lung ston gyis ji ltar bshad pa dang / rdo rje 'phreng ba la sogs pa gsum gyis ji ltar bshad pa'o/ /
1.The explanations of the Later Tantra and the Explanation of the Intention Tantra 2.The explanations of the Vajra Garland and the other two explanatory tantras
dang po [rgyud phyi ma dang dgongs pa lung ston gyis ji ltar bshad pa] ni/
The explanations of the Later Tantra and the Explanation of the Intention Tantra

'dus pa'i bshad rgyud gzhan ni de'i bshad rgyud yin kyang 'dus pa'i rgyud min la/ rgyud phyi ma ni de gnyis ka yin no/ / 'dis rtsa rgyud 'chad tshul la/ rgyud kyi thun mong gi don 'chad pa ni dpal gsang ba 'dus pa rnal 'byor gyi rgyud ces pa'i mtshan don dang thabs rgyud kyi dbye ba dang rgyud spyi'i sdom la dris lan mdzad pa rnams yin la/ lhag ma rnams ni le'u bcu bdun po so so'i don la dris lan mdzad pa'o/ / rgyud kyi 'grel pa dris pa'i 'grel pa ni gang bshad pas rgyud kyi don thams cad khrig chags su 'brel ba'i phun sum tshogs pa yin la/ de ni dpal gyi don du nA ro pa bzhed do/ / de'i lan du le'u gnyis pa nas bcu bdun pa'i bar bcu drug gi bzhi tshan re res bsnyen sgrub yan lag bzhi'i re re ston par bshad pa la/ nA ro pas le'u dang pos rgyud don mdor bstan pa lhag ma bcu drug gis bsnyen sgrub yan lag bzhir 'chad cing / bco brgyad pa ni de thams cad kyi gsang ba'i man ngag ston par gsungs so/ / de dag gis ni rim gnyis so sor ma phye bar rim gnyis thun mong gi bsnyen sgrub yan lag bzhi bstan la/ thabs rgyud kyi dbye ba'i skabs su rim gnyis so sor phye ba'i bsnyen sgrub yan lag bzhi bstan no/ /

Other Guhyasamāja explanatory tantras are explanatory tantras of that tantra, but they are not Guhyasamāja tantra. The Later Tantra is both. The way it explains the Root Tantra is: The explanations of points that are common to the tantra as a whole include: the meaning of the “Glorious Guhyasamāja Yoga Tantra” title of the tantra, the divisions of method tantra, and the general principles of the tantra, all of which are in the form of questions and answers. The rest of the text deals with the seventeen chapters individually, also in question-and-answer form. The “connections” mentioned in the question about the connections[64] within the tantra are the perfect arrangement of all points of the tantra as elucidated by the Later Tantra. It is this that Nāropa describes as being the meaning of “glorious.” In its answer to this question, the Later Tantra explains how four groups of four chapters from the second through to the seventeenth teach the four branches of approach (sevā) and accomplishment (sādhana). Nāropa says[65] that the first chapter teaches the tantra in synopsis, the remaining sixteen teach the branches of approach and accomplishment, while the eighteenth teaches the hidden core teachings[66] within them all. Without designating generation or completion stage, these chapters teach the four branches common to both stages. When teaching the divisions of method tantra, however, it explains the four branches in relation to each of the two stages.

bshad rgyud rnams la thun mong ma yin pa'i rtsal du 'don phyogs re'i sgo nas rtsa rgyud 'chad tshul re yod pa la/ rgyud phyi ma 'dis ni rtsa rgyud kyi le'u bcu gnyis par gsungs pa'i bsnyen sgrub yan lag bzhi'i sgo nas rtsa rgyud 'chad la/ 'grel pa'i don dpal gyi dris lan du le'u bcu drug gis bsnyen sgrub bzhi 'chad pa byung bas le'u so so'i dris lan rnams der 'du zhing / thabs rgyud kyi dbye ba'i dris lan ni mtshan don gyi dris lan nyid yin pa dang / spyi don yang mtshan don gyi dris lan du 'du bas/ rtsa rgyud kyi gzhung ni gtso bor rgyud kyi mtshan gyi gzhung nyid 'chad pa la sbyar na shin tu ngo mtshar bskyed par byed do/ /

Each of the explanatory tantras explain the Root Tantra with its own special emphasis. For example, the Later Tantra explains the Root Tantra in terms of the four branches of approach and accomplishment that are spoken of in chapter 12 of the Root Tantra. Within the answer to the question on the meaning of “glorious” in the title of the tantra, which refers to the “connections” within the tantra, it explains how the sixteen chapters teach the four branches. Therefore, within that answer are included answers to questions on the individual chapters. The answers to the questions on the divisions of method tantra are the answers to the meaning of the title. Moreover, general principles of the tantra are included within the answers to questions on the title. Therefore, if the text of the main body of the Root Tantra is applied in the main to the explanation of the text of the title of the tantra, it will generate a true sense of wonder and amazement.

'di la ni le'u bzhi bzhis bsnyen sgrub yan lag re re bstan par 'gro tshul dka' bas de legs par thon pa dang rim gnyis so so'i yan lag bzhi'i sa mtshams legs par phyed pa dang / khyad par du rdzogs rim gyi bsnyen pa'i yan lag drug bshad pa rnams legs par rtogs nas rtsa rgyud 'chad shes pa cig dgos te/ 'phags lugs kyis rgyud phyi ma de ltar 'chad shes pa ni nA ro pa'i 'grel pa nyid la rag las par snang ngo/ / dgongs pa lung ston ni rtsa rgyud dang le'u yi rim pa rnams mthun zhing / le'u rnams su rtsa rgyud las gang gsungs pa phal che ba bkod nas de nas le'u de'i dka' gnas rnams 'chad pa zhig go /rgyud 'dir le'u bcu bdun po so sos don 'di ston pa bsdus pa re gsungs shing / 'dus pa'i rgyud sgra ji bzhin par bshad du mi rung bar bstan nas/ drang don gsungs pa rnams kyi nges don sbas pa rnams gsal bar mdzad cing / don gzhan la sgra 'gal ba gzhan gyis gsungs pa'i dgongs bshad rnams kyang legs par bkral la/ le'u so so phal che bar rdo rje bzlas pa rtsa rgyud du sbas nas gsungs pa rnams yang dang yang du gsal bar ston par mdzad do/ / des na 'dis rtsal du bton nas rtsa rgyud 'chad pa yang rim pa de dag gi sgo nas yin no/ / sgron gsal du bshad rgyud khungs su drangs pa la 'di mang shos su yod de de shas cher nges don gyi bshad pa la drangs so/ /

It is difficult to perceive how groups of four chapters explain the four branches of approach and accomplishment. Therefore it is necessary to have a tradition that knows how to explain the Root Tantra in ways that brings this out clearly, that has determined the boundaries of the four branches within each of the two stages, and in particular, that has understood the explanations of the six branches of approach and so on within the completion stage. [18] You should rely upon Nāropa’s commentary to understand that the Ārya tradition knows how to explain the Later Tantra in this way. The Explanation of the Intention follows the Root Tantra according to the order and number of the chapters. In each chapter it mostly cites the Root Tantra and explains the difficult points of that chapter. This tantra states that the points taught in the seventeen chapters of the Root Tantra are in brief form, it explains that the Guhyasamāja is not to be taken literally, and it proceeds to bring out the hidden definitive meanings of those passages taught provisionally. It also clarifies the metaphorical expressions that are exclusive and seemingly contradictory.[67] In most chapters it brings out again and again instances of vajra repetition being taught in a hidden way within the Root Tantra. Therefore this is the particular emphasis that this work puts on its explanation of the Root Tantra. In Candrakīrti’s Illuminating Lamp, when it uses explanatory tantras as reference, this tantra is quoted the most, and it is cited as expressing the definitive meaning.
gnyis pa [rdo rje 'phreng ba la sogs pa gsum gyis ji ltar bshad pa] ni/
The explanations of the Vajra Garland and the other two explanatory tantras

rdo rje 'phreng ba nyung ngu'i rgyud 'di la le'u bcu dgu pa dang nyi shu pa'i gzhung gi gcod mtshams mi 'dra ba gsum byung ste/ 'di ltar le'u bcu dgu pa'i thog ma/ de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / sna tshogs la sogs skad cig bdag /ces pa nas/ rnam pa sna tshogs mngon par 'dod/ ces pa'i bar gyi tshig rkang dgu ma gtogs pa de'i rjes nas le'u bcu dgu pa'i mthar thug pa'i gzhung ma dar bas 'di bzhag pa'o zhes 'grel par bshad la/ de'i rjes su/ de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ zhes pa nas/ bla ma brgyud pa las shes bya/ zhes pa'i bar la le'u nyi shu par mdzad nas spyir le'u re brgyad du 'grel par byas so/ / lha bla ma zhi ba 'od kyis bsgyur ba la/ rnam pa sna tshogs mngon par 'dod/ ces pa yan chad sngar dang 'dra ba la/ de'i rjes su/
blta dang 'gugs dang de bzhin brda/ / kha la cum pa byed pa yi/ / dga' ba nyams su myong bar shes/ / zhes pa nas/ lhan cig skyes dga' nyams myong ba/ / mtshan nyid dang bral skad cig go /
zhes pa'i bar du bton nas de rnams la le'u bcu dgu pa skad cig ma rnam par phye ba'i le'ur mdzad cing /
de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / dga' ba bzhi yi mtshan nyid ni/ / zhes pa nas/ sprul pa'i 'khor lor lhan cig skyes/ / dga' ba nyams su myong bar byed/ /
ces pa'i bar du bton nas de'i 'og tu/ rtsa rnams kun gyi nam mkha' che/ /zhes pa nas/ bla ma brgyud pa las shes bya/ /zhes pa'i bar gyis le'u nyi shu pa dga' ba'i mtshan nyid rnam par phye ba'i le'u zhes mdzad de/ spyir le'u re brgyad du byas so/ /

In the condensed Vajra Garland there are three different ways of dividing up the text of the nineteenth and twentieth chapters. According to the Vajra Garland commentary,[68] chapter 19 begins: Now I will explain more: occasions of the diverse, and so on.[69] And only runs for nine lines up to: Desiring the diverse. After this, it is explained, “the end of the text of chapter 19 is not available and so will be left uncommented.” It then designates chapter 20, beginning “Now, I will explain more,” up to “will be known from the transmission of guru.” As a whole the commentary covers sixty-eight chapters. The Vajra Garland translation by Lha Lama Shiwa Ö[70] follows the above up to the line “Desiring the diverse.” After that come the lines:
… will experience the joy of looking, calling, gesturing, and kissing on the lips. Up to: Experiencing the innate joy is the occasion called free of definition.
These lines constitute chapter 19 on the types of occasions. This is followed by:
Now I will explain more: the definitions of the four joys. Up to: In the emanation cakra the innate joy is experienced.
After this the text runs, “The great space of all three channels” up to “will be known from the transmission of the guru.” All these constitute chapter 20 on the definition of the joys. The whole tantra takes up sixty-eight chapters. [19]

zhi ba 'od kyi 'gyur dar ma brtson 'grus kyis bcos pa las/ rnam pa sna tshogs mngon par 'dod/ /ces pa yan chad sngar dang 'dra ba la/ de'i rjes su /
de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ / dga' ba bzhi yi mtshan nyid ni/ / zhes pa nas/ sprul pa'i 'khor lor lhan cig skyes/ / dga' ba nyams su myong bar byed/ /
ces pa'i bar du 'don no/ / de'i 'og tu/
blta dang 'gugs dang de bzhin brda/ / zhes pa nas/ lhan cig skyes dga' nyams myong ba/ / mtshan nyid dang bral skad cig go /
zhes pa'i bar du 'don zhing / de'i 'og tu/ rtsa rnams kun gyi nam mkha' che/ / zhes pa nas/ bla ma brgyud pa las shes bya/ /
zhes pa'i bar rnams bton te/ de rnams kun dga' ba'i mtshan nyid rnam par phye ba zhes bya ba le'u bcu dgu par byas nas/ spyir le'u re bdun du byas so/ /

The translation made by Shiwa Ö and revised by Darma Tsöndru (1117–92) follows the above versions up to the line “Desiring the diverse.” After that:
Now I will explain more: the definitions of the four joys. Up to: In the emanation cakra the innate joy is experienced.
After this comes:
looking, calling, gesturing … Up to: Experiencing the innate joy is the occasion called free of definition.
After this, it runs, “The great space of all three channels” up to “will be known from the transmission of the guru.” All of this constitutes the nineteenth chapter on the types of joy. As a whole, this edition has sixty-seven chapters.

de ltar mi mthun pa mang du snang yang paN+Di ta mAn+t+ra ka la sha'i rgya dpe dang su dza na shrI dz+nyA na dang / zhi ba 'od kyis bsgyur ba'i le'u yi gcod mtshams de nyid gzhung gi don du snang ste/ skad cig ma bzhi lugs 'byung dang lugs ldog tu bshad pa'i tshan gcig dang / dga' ba bzhi lugs ba bzhi lugs 'byung dang lugs ldog tu bshad pa'i chan pa gnyis gzhung la snang ba'i phyir dang / blta dang 'gugs dang de bzhin brda/ zhes sogs ni/ rnam pa sna tshogs mngon par 'dod/ ces pa'i 'phror shin tu gsal ba'i phyir dang / de nas gzhan yang bshad bya ba/ zhes pa'i tshig ni le'u gzhan du ma la yang le'u yi mgo 'dren gyi tshig tu gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

It can be seen that there are many discrepancies, but the Indian work by Pandit Māntrakalaśa[71] and the chapter division as translated by Sujana Śrījñāna and Shiwa Ö[72] appear to be closer to the meaning of the tantra. This is because the four instances explained in forward and reverse orders and the four joys explained in forward and reverse orders constitute two separate topics of the text, and the section verse on “looking, calling, gesturing” clearly follows on from “Desiring the diverse.” Also the words “Now I will explain more” are used many times in this text as the opening line of a new chapter.

rgyud 'dir phyag rdor gyis gsang ba 'dus par brda tsam gyis mi gsal bar gsungs pa'i rim gnyis la rdo rje 'phreng ba'i sgo nas 'dri 'dod pas/ gtso bor rdzogs rim gyi sgo nas bstan du gsol zhes pa'i ngag sngon du btang nas rdo rje 'phreng ba'i ming don nas rlung gi mtshan nyid dang 'jig tshul gyi bar gyi dri ba mdzad do/ / de rnams kyi lan gyis phal cher 'dus pa'i don dang / mngon brjod 'bum pa sogs rnal 'byor ma'i rgyud kyi don mang po yang bshad de/ de yang phal mo che 'dus pa'i don gyi mtha' gcod pa'i yan lag tu snang ngo/ / dris lan gyi grangs ni brgyad cu gya gnyis su 'grel pas bshad do/ / rgyud 'dis gsal kha bton nas 'dus pa'i gzhung gang 'chad snyam na/ rtsa rgyud kyi le'u gsum pa dang drug par sna rtser yungs kar tsam gyi rin chen bsgom par gsungs pa sogs mang po zhig 'chad mod kyang / gtso bo ni e waM ma yA la sogs pa'i yi ge bzhi bcu'i gleng gzhis rgyud kyi don thams cad bsdus par sgron gsal las gsungs pa de rgyud 'dir/ e ni shes rab dam pa ste/ zhes sogs tshigs bcad bzhi bcu'i tshigs bcad ras yi ge re'i don 'chad pa 'di yin no/ / gzhung de dag gis lus dben dang / ngag dben dang / sems dben dang bsgyu lus rnams gtso bor bstan la/ skabs gzhan du 'od gsal dang zung 'jug kyang mang du stan pas rdzogs rim tshang bar ston no/ / de'i lam gyi chings kyang rim lngar mdzad de/ de nyid las/
rdo rje bzlas par rab sbyor bas/ / rlung gi mtshan nyid shes nas ni/ / rnam rtog rlung rnams rnam par gcod/ / sems la dmigs pa thob par 'gyur/ / bdag la byin brlabs rim pas kyang / / dngos grub brgyad ni thob par 'gyur/ / snang ba la sogs dbye ba shes/ / mngon par byang chub pa ni 'thob/ / zung 'jug rim pa la gnas pa/ / dngos grub thams cad bsdus pa ni/ / tshe 'di nyid la 'grub 'gyur bar/ / rnal 'byor pa yis the tshom med/ / ces gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

In this tantra Vajrapāṇi wishes to ask questions, by way of the vajra garland,[73] on the two stages that were only taught briefly, and therefore unclearly, within the Guhyasamāja. He begins with the plea to teach primarily by way of the completion stage and asks questions on the meaning of the term vajra garland and so on up to the section on the definitions of the winds and their destruction. Mostly the answers cover many topics from the Guhyasamāja, as well as from yoginī tantras such as the Hundred Thousand Abhidāna Tantra,[74] and thus form a supplement to conclusively determine the various topics within the Guhyasamāja. The questions are said by the commentary to number eighty-two. Which parts of the Guhyasamāja text does this tantra elucidate? While this text elaborates on the meditation of the mustard seed–sized jewel on the tip of the nose spoken of in the third and sixth chapters of the root text, the primary focus is on the forty syllables of the introduction, e, vaṃ, ma, yā, and so on. In Candrakīrti’s Illuminating Lamp, these are said to summarize the entire tantra. In the Vajra Garland they are taught in forty verses, beginning “e is the sacred wisdom,”[75] each verse explaining one of the syllables. These passages mainly teach body isolation, speech isolation, mind isolation, and illusory body. [20] Elsewhere, clear light and union are taught in abundance. Therefore the completion stage is covered in its entirety. It also arranges the themes of the completion-stage path into the five stages:
By the yoga of vajra repetition, knowing the characteristics of the winds, the winds of conceptualization are severed, and you gain focus upon the mind. By the stage of self-consecration, you gain the eight siddhis. Knowing the types of appearances, you attain the stage of mastery. Dwelling in the state of union, the composite of every siddhi in this very life will, without doubt, be gained by the yogi.[76]

mgon po klu sgrub kyis rdzogs rim rim lngar bsdus pa ni rgyud 'di yi rjes su 'brangs pa yin la/ bskyed rim la ting nge 'dzin gsum dang / rnal 'byor bzhi dang / lha so gnyis su mdzad pa la sogs pa yang rgyud 'di'i rjes su 'brangs pa'o/ / des na mdor byas las rje btsun gyis srub mkhan mdzad nas rdo rje 'phreng ba'i srub shing gis gsang 'dus sbas chu'i rgya mtsho bsrubs pa las 'dus pa'i sgrub thabs rnyed par gsungs pa ni bskyed rim tsam la mi gzung ngo/ / 'dod chags chos sbas kyi phyi'i phyag rgya dang / rdo rje bzlas pa sogs kyi srog rtsol la brten nas stong pa bzhi dang sgyu ma'i sku 'dren pa'i phyi nang gi srog rtsol mtha' chod par nges pa'i yan lag tu gnas pa rtsa dang g.yo ba rlung dang bkod pa byang chub kyi sems la brtsams nas lus 'chags pa dang 'jig pa'i rim pa du ma bshad nas/ thabs de gnyis las mngon par rtogs pa'i rim pa 'char tshul sogs mtha' yas pa cig 'chad do/ / lam gyi snod rung du sgrub pa'i dbang gi chings rnams cho ga nyi shur sdud pa dang / bskyed rim sdud pa'i chings rnams dang / rim gnyis kyi go rim nges pa sogs mang po yang gsungs shing / khyad par du srog rtsol rdo rje bzlas pas snying kha'i rtsa mdud 'byed pa'i gnad rnams le'u drug pa dang / snying kha'i rtsa mdud 'grol ba 'khor lo thams cad kyi rtsa mdud 'grol ba'i mchog yin tshul le'u nyer gnyis pa'i yi ge gsum gyi nges don gyi sngags btu ba las 'chad de/ legs par thon pa nyung bar byung snang ngo/ /

The guide and protector Nāgārjuna’s compilation of the completion stage into five stages follows this tantra. Also, his presentation of the three samādhis, the four yogas, the thirty-two deities, and so on within the generation stage are based on this tantra. Therefore, in his Condensed Sādhana,[77] when the venerable one as the churner talks of having churned the ocean of the hidden waters of the Guhyasamāja with the churning rod of the Vajra Garland to discover the Guhyasamāja sādhana, it should not be taken as referring solely to the generation stage. It also clarifies the stages of creation and dissolution of the body beginning from the stationary channels, the moving winds, and the placed drops. This acts as secondary material helping to ascertain and determine the outer and inner prāṇāyāma practices, such as the secret outer mudrā desire practice, vajra repetition, and so on, from which the four empty states and the illusory body are induced. It then goes on to explain the appearance of the levels of insight arising from these two methods and so on, as well as many other points. The Vajra Garland also compiles into twenty rituals the themes of the initiations that render a person fit for the path. It teaches the themes of the generation stage and determines with certainty the order of the two stages. In particular, in chapter 6, it shows the places where you open up the channel knots of the heart by the practice of prāṇāyāma vajra repetition. The manner in which untying the channel knots of the heart is superior to untying the channel knots at the other cakras is explained in chapter 22, which deals with the definitive mantra compilation of the three syllables. All of the above is well brought out by using few words.

rgyud 'dis 'dus pa rtsal du bton nas 'chad tshul ni/ gleng gzhi'i yi ge re'i don bshad pas 'dus par gab pa'i don rnams gsal bar 'don la/ de nyid kyi mtha' gcod pa'i yan lag tu bshad rgyud kyi gzhung gzhan rnams 'gro ba'i tshul 'di rim gnyis kyi chings byas pa rnams kyi sgo nas shes par byas nas 'chad pa cig dgos so/ / bshad rgyud la 'di las bzang ba sngar ma 'gyur zhes 'di'i 'gyur byang las 'byung ba ni da dung yang de kho na ltar snang ngo/ / lha mo bzhis zhus kyis ni gtso bor srog rtsal gyi gnad rnams rgyas par 'chad la/ ye shes rdo rje kun las btus kyis ni 'dus pa gtso bor byas pa'i rnal 'byor bla med kyi rgyud rnams 'chad pa'i man ngag gi mthar thug rgyan bdun ston te/ stong pa gsum dang de las sgyu ma'i sku sgrub pa ni bshad rgyud gzhan las 'di gsal lo/ / rgyud de gnyis kyis 'dus pa 'chad tshul rgyas par ni de gnyis kyi rgya cher bshad pa las bshad zin pas 'dir rgyas par ma smos so/ / de ltar rje btsun yab sras kyi man ngag gi gzhung rnams la ring du 'dris pas don gyi gnad lags par thon pa'i lde mig gis rtsa rgyud kyi sgo la mtha' drug dang tshul bzhis rgyas btab pa'i don bshad rgyud rnams dang legs par shan sbyar bas rtsa rgyud kyi sgo phyed pa cig byung na/ rgyud kyi gdams ngag la mi 'jigs pa thob pa'i gdams ngag can du 'gro ba yin la/ de ltar shes na rgyud gzhan la'ang de'i rigs pa sbyor shes pas rgyud sde kun la mkhas par 'gyur ro/ /

The way this tantra concentrates specifically on Guhyasamāja is as follows: By explaining the forty syllables of the introduction, it brings out clearly points that are hidden in the Guhyasamāja. The other explanatory tantras are secondary for the clarification of these difficult points of the Guhyasamāja, and to understand how this is the case requires explanations based on knowing how this tantra defines the two stages. In the translator’s colophon of the Vajra Garland it says, “No explanatory tantra better than this has appeared before.” This is still the case. [21] The Tantra Requested by the Four Goddesses explains extensively and primarily the points of prāṇāyāma. The Vajra Wisdom Compendium teaches the seven ornaments,[78] which represent the ultimate core teaching for explaining the highest yoga tantras as exemplified by the Guhyasamāja. In doing so, its explanation of the three empty states and how the illusory body is developed from them is clearer than in other explanatory tantras. An extensive description of how these two tantras explain Guhyasamāja can be found in the extensive commentaries[79] to these two tantras, and so I will not go into detail here. Therefore extensive familiarization with the texts containing the core teachings of the venerable one and his disciples is the key that brings out the essential points of the tantra. That key together with the explanatory tantras will open that door of the Root Tantra sealed by the four modes and six sides. When that happens, you will become a fearless holder of instructions within this tantra. With such an understanding, you will know how to apply this reasoning to other tantras and thus become learned in all classes of tantra.
4. Praise of Guhyasamāja
gnyis pa ['dus pa'i che ba brjod pa] ni/
The greatness of Guhyasamāja

rtsa ba'i rgyud las mtshan brjod pa'i skabs su de bzhin gshegs pa thams cad kyi sku gsung thugs kyi gsang ba kun rgyud 'dir 'dus par gsungs te/ des ni rdo rje theg pa'i gsang ba'i gnad thams cad 'dir 'dus par bstan no/ / rgyud phyi ma las kyang /
e ma ho shin tu rnyed dka' ba/ / byang chub sgrub pa'i thabs 'di yin/ / rgyud kyi phyi ma'i phyi mar gyur/ / gsang ba 'dus pa zhes bya'i rgyud/ /
ces gsungs so/ / shin tu rnyed dka' zhing don che bas 'di la thun bzhi'i rnal 'byor byed pa dang / nyan pa dang 'dri 'don dang mchod pa byed pa la yang byang chub rdo rje rdo rje 'chang dang 'dra bar bltas nas phyag bya bar gsungs shing / der ma zad rgyud de'i sgrub pa po'i dbang po de gang gis mthong thos dran reg dang / dad par byed cing rgyud kyi phyogs gcig tsam zhig 'dzin pa yan chad la'ang rdo rje 'chang dang 'dra bar bltas nas phyag bya bar gsungs te/ rgyud phyi ma las/
gang zhig thun bzhi'i rdo rje dag ni sgrub byed cing / / mi snang la sogs sna tshogs mchog dang dman grub cing / / bla ma'i drin gyis 'di na ma nor lam rtogs pa/ / byang chub rdo rje 'drar blta de la rtag phyag 'tshal/ / gang zhig rab gsang 'dus pa'i rgyud 'di nyan pa dang / / 'don par byed dang klog pa dang ni sems pa dang / / mchod par byed pa dang ni 'dri 'am 'drir 'jug pa/ / byang chub rdo rje 'drar blta de la rtag phyag 'tshal/ /
zhes dang /
gang gis gtso bo sgrub pa po mthong reg pa dang / / legs par dran dang ming tsam nges par thos pa dang / / dad par byed cing phyogs gcig tsam zhig 'dzin pa dag / byang chub rdo rje 'drar blta de la rtag phyag 'tshal/ /
zhes gsungs so/ /
'jam dpal gyi zhal gyi lung las kyang / sangs rgyas kun gyi 'dus pa'i rgyud/ / gsang chen gsang ba ches gsang ba/ / gong na med pa'i lung chen po/ /
zhes bsngags shing /

In the Root Tantra, in the section on the title, it states that every secret of the body, speech, and mind of every tathāgata is contained within this tantra. This is saying that every essential secret point of the Vajra Vehicle is contained within it. The Later Tantra also says:
Emaho! So difficult to find, this method of gaining enlightenment, the supreme of supreme tantras,[80] the Guhyasamāja Tantra.[81]
Because it is so hard to find, and of such great significance, it is said that those who practice its four-session yoga, who listen to it, copy it, recite it, and make offerings to it, are to be regarded as being like Bodhivajra or Vajradhara and worthy of prostration. Also, those who merely see, hear, remember, or come into contact with master practitioners of this tantra, or even those who have faith in them up to those who hold just a part of this tantra, all are also to be regarded as being like Vajradhara and are objects of prostration. The Later Tantra says:
Those who practice the vajra of the four sessions, accomplish the powers of invisibility and so forth— the various siddhis, supreme and ordinary— and, by the kindness of their guru, find here the unmistaken path are regarded as being like Bodhivajra, and prostrations are made to them. Whoever listens to, recites, reads, contemplates, makes offering to, writes, or encourages others to write the supreme tantra of Guhyasamāja are regarded as being like Bodhivajra, and prostrations are made to them.[82]
Also:
Of the prime practitioners, those who see, touch, and remember them, [22] who just hear their name, who have faith, and those who merely possess a part, are regarded as being like Bodhivajra, and prostrations are made to them.[83]
Also it is praised in Oral Teachings of Mañjuśrī; The tantra that gathers every buddha— great secret, so secret, so very secret— a teaching of which there is none higher.[84]

bstan pa'i snying po gnas mi gnas kyang 'di nyid yod med kyi rjes su byed par der gsungs te/
'di don rna bar 'pho byed pa/ / gang gi dus su gnas pa der/ / sangs rgyas bstan pa rin chen kyang / / gnas par rab tu bshad pa yis/ / brgyud pa'i rim pa 'di chad nas/ / sangs rgyas bstan pa nub pa ru/ / kun gyis rab tu shes par bya/ /
zhes so/ /

This work also says that the presence of the very heart of the doctrine depends upon this tantra being in existence:
At the time its meaning enters the ears, at that place the precious doctrine of the Buddha is said to abide there also. When its transmission is cut, the doctrine of the Buddha will cease. This all should know.[85]

rgyud 'di'i sker du de ltar byung bar ma zad rgyud gzhan las kyang bsngags te/ dmar nag gi rgyud gnyis las/
rgyud kyi mthar thug 'dus pa ste/ / ma byung 'byung bar mi 'gyur ro/ / zhes gsungs so/ / gsang ba grub pa las kyang / dpal ldan 'dus las mchog gzhan med/ / 'jig rten gsum gyi rin chen 'gyur/ / snying po las ni snying po mchog / rgyud kun gyi ni bla ma'i bla/ / bstan dang bshad pa rnam gnas na/ / rdzogs pa'i rnal 'byor rim pa nyid/ / 'dus pa gang gis mi shes pa/ / de yis dngos grub ji ltar 'grub/ / the tshom thams cad gcod byed cing / / mi shes rab rib sel byed pa/ / sangs rgyas rin chen za ma tog / dpal ldan 'dus pa yongs spangs nas/ / rnam rtog du mas brtags pa yis/ / rmongs pa dngos grub 'dod gyur pa/ / mkha' la khu tshur rdeg pa dang / / smig rgyu'i chu la 'thung ba bzhin/ / zhes dang / sgron gsal las kyang / ji srid ya ra la ha'i bar/ / ka kha g+ha mtha' Na jo'i mtha'/ / tra d+ha'i mtha' dang ma mthar bcas/ / de de'i rtsa ba yi ge gsum/ / thub pa chen pos chos phung po/ / brgyad khri bzhi stong gsungs ba yi/ / dpal ldan 'dus 'di snod yin te/ / de bas de ni rgyud kyi rtse/ /
zhes rgyud sde gzhan kun gyi rtsa ba dang / mdo sde kun gyi za ma tog tu gyur pas rgyud sde kun gyi rtse mor gsungs so/ / ye shes rdo rje kun las btus las ka la sogs pa re re'i mtha' can gyi rgyud la'ang rgyud sde stong phrag rer bshad cing / de yang rgyud sde bzhi ka'i dbang du mdzad nas gsungs so/ / gsal byed kyi yi ge'i mtha' can gyi rgyud sde'i rtsa bar gsungs pa ni mtshon pa tsam yin pas/ dbyangs kyi yi ge rnams kyi mtha' can gyi rgyud sde'i rtsa bar yang bstan par slob dpon skal ldan grags pa dang ku mA ras bshad do/ /

Such praise is not only found in the corpus of this tantra, but other tantras also give it praise. The Red and Black Yamāri Tantras say:
The ultimate tantra, the Guhyasamāja— without it, they will not arise.[86] The Guhyasiddhi also: No tantra is higher than glorious Guhyasamāja: a jewel among the three worlds, the essence of even the essence, the highest of high tantras. Where its doctrine and teachings exist, there exist the stages of the complete yoga. Those who do not know the Guhyasamāja, how will they gain siddhi? It cuts all doubt and clears away the murkiness of ignorance. It is the amulet carrying the doctrine of the Buddha. Having completely abandoned the Guhyasamāja and conceptualizing with many a thought, the fool hoping to gain siddhi like this is punching the air with a fist and drinking the water of a mirage.[87] Illuminating Lamp also cites: From the letters ya, ra, la, and ha, to those ending in ka, kha, and gha, those ending in ṇa and ja, in da and dha, and in ma, it is their three-letter root. Of the eighty-four thousand Dharma categories spoken by the mighty one, this glorious Guhyasamāja is the container; therefore, it is the pinnacle of the tantras.[88]
Therefore the Guhyasamāja is the root of all other classes of tantra, and because it is the amulet holding all the sutras, it is the pinnacle of all classes of tantra. Vajra Wisdom Compendium[89] explains that there are a thousand tantras for each of those tantras ending with ka, and so on, and that this is being asserted on the basis of all four classes of tantra. Also, stating that the Guhyasamāja is the root of all tantras ending in consonant forms is just an illustration, and thus both Ācarya Bhavyakīrti[90] and Kumāra[91] explain that Guhyasamāja is also the root of tantras ending in vowel forms.

rtsa ba yi ge gsum zhes gsungs pa'i yi ge gsum ni nA ro bas 'bru gsum la bshad la/ bod kyi gong ma rnams sa mA ji la bzhed do/ / de'i snga ma ni gsang ba 'dus pa'i 'du rgyu gsang ba gsum sku gsung thugs la rgyud phyi mar bshad pas/ 'du rgyu'i sgo nas 'dus pa ngos bzung ba'o/ / de ltar 'dus pa'i rgyud la mi byed par rgyud thams cad kyi don yi ge gsum gyi don rdo rje gsum du 'du ba la bshad na skabs don bor bar 'gyur te/ des ni 'dus pa'i rgyud rgyud sde thams cad kyi rtsa bar ston pa'i phyir ro/ / rtsa ba'i don ni shing sdong po la yal ga dang lo ma sogs du ma zhig yid kyang / gang du 'du ba'i gnas rtsa ba yin pa ltar rgyud sde rnams la don mi 'dra ba du ma zhig yod kyang / de dag gi gnad thams cad mthar thug na 'dus pa'i lam du 'du ba'i don te/ mdo sde'i snod kyang de dang 'dra'o/ / 'dis ni 'di'i lam rdzogs par 'chang shes na 'di las mchog tu gyur pa gzhan na med par ston pa'o/ / nag po spyod pas rim pa gnyis ka la 'dus pa'i lam lhag pa dang / rgyud kun gyi gtso bo yin pa'i sgo nas bsngags pa ni sngar drangs zin to/ / bla med kyi rgyud rnams la rgyud sde 'og ma gsum bzhin du rgyud sde'i rim pa'i sgo nas mchog dman med kyang khyad par 'ga' zhig la bltos pa'i mchog dman med pa ni min te/ dper na rgyud sde gcig gis rim gnyis ston pa'i gzhung la nang tshan gyi mchog dman yod kyang / de gnyis la rgyud sde'i rim pa'i sgo nas mchog dman med pa bzhin no/ /

Concerning the “three letters” in the phrase “three-letter root,” Nāropa[92] explains them as the three seed syllables, but earlier Tibetans asserted them to be the three syllables sa mā ja. [23] For the former assertion, the three secrets to be gathered in the term gathering of secrets (guhyasamāja) is explained by the Later Tantra as referring to the enlightened body, speech, and mind. In this sense “gathering” here refers to what is gathered.[93] Not applying this to the Guhyasamāja Tantra itself but to all tantras gathered into the three vajras in the form of the three letters is to lose the context here, because the previous citation is teaching that the Guhyasamāja Tantra is the root of all other classes of tantra. As for the meaning of root, a tree may have many branches, leaves, and so on, but the place where they all gather is the trunk. Likewise, there are many different meanings taught in the types of tantra, but all their essential points are ultimately gathered in the path of Guhyasamāja. In this way it is comparable to the basket of sutras. The above is saying that if this path is understood and explained completely, there is nothing superior elsewhere. In a passage cited previously, Kṛṣṇācārya praised the extraordinary path of Guhyasamāja in both stages and called it the most important of all tantras. Within the highest yoga tantras there are no greater or lesser tantras in terms of there being different categories, as there are in the three lower classes of tantra. Nonetheless, it is not the case that there are no greater or lesser tantras in terms of there being some differences between them. For example, in the teaching of the two stages by one particular group of tantras, there will be greater and lesser texts, but these two types of texts are not greater and lesser by virtue of belonging to different categories.
5. Commentarial Traditions
gsum pa [de'i dgongs pa 'grel ba'i rim pa] ni/
Commentarial traditions on the meaning of Guhyasamāja

in+t+ra b+hu ti chen po dang klu'i rnal 'byor ma dang sa bdag bi su kalpa sa gzhung mdzad pa ni 'di na mi snang la/ dpal mgon po bde ba chen pos ni 'dus pa'i don gtan la 'bebs pa gsang ba grub pa mdzad do/ / 'dis 'dus pa'i gzhung ni gtso bor gleng gzhi gtan la 'bebs la/ lam gyi rim pa ni dang por yi ge 'god pa'i bskyed rim gnyis pa las rgyal brten nas rang gi rang bzhin de kho na nyid mtshon par byed pa/ gsum pa de brtan pa'i don du ye shes kyi phyag rgya la brten nas sgom pa/ bzhi pa phyag rgya chen po mngon par byang chub pa sgom pa bzhi spyod pa dang bcas pa ston no/ / 'dis 'dus pa'i dkyil 'khor gyi lha grangs bcu bdun du mdzad ces pa ni de nyid las/ byang chub sems dpa' bcu bdun gyi go rim gyis nges par rdzogs par gyur nas/ zhes bcu bdun gyis rdzogs zhes pa tsam la bsams par snang la/ de lta na sgron gsal las/ de las gang gi lha'i 'khor lo yongs su rdzogs par gyur pa de tsam nyid cig bstan pa'i phyir/ zhes gleng gzhi'i 'khor gyi skabs su gsungs pas lha so gnyis kyi dkyil 'khor mi 'dod par 'gyur ro/ / des na de'i don ni gshegs pa gshegs ma dang sems dpa' sems ma'i 'khor gang gis dkyil 'khor gyi lha rdzogs pa de tsam zhig gleng gzhir bstan zhes pa'i don yin la/ snga ma'i don ni rigs lnga ma gtogs pa'i gleng gzhi'i 'khor dngos su smos pa rnams sems dpar byas nas/ de dag gis dngos su smos pa'i byang sems kyi 'khor rdzogs zhes pa'i don no/ /

No works composed by Indrabhūti the Great, Nāgayoginī, and King Viśukalpa have appeared. Śrī Mahāsukhanātha composed the Guhyasiddhi, which ascertains the meaning of the Guhyasamāja. On the actual text of the Guhyasamāja, the Guhyasiddhi principally ascertains the meaning of the preface. For the stages of the path of the Guhyasamāja, first it describes the generation stage involving the placement of the syllables. Second, it teaches how the reality of your actual nature is revealed through reliance upon a karma consort. Third, it teaches the meditation to stabilize that understanding by relying upon a wisdom consort. And fourth, it explains the meditation on perfecting the mahāmudrā consort, together with a section on tantric activities. The assertion that “in this work the number of deities in the mandala is seventeen” comes from merely considering a citation from that work that states: “It is definitely completed by the arrangement of the seventeen bodhisattvas.”[94] The statement from Candrakīrti’s Illuminating Lamp that says, “Because of the number by which the deity assembly is completed in that work, that particular number is taught,”[95] comes from the section on the preface, and so there is no need for a thirty-two-deity mandala. [24] The meaning of this statement is that “by the number” of the assembly of male tathāgatas, female tathāgatas, male bodhisattvas, and female bodhisattvas, “by which the deity assembly is completed in that work, that particular number is taught” in the preface. The meaning of the Guhyasiddhi citation is that with the exception of the five buddha families, the assembly of deities actually mentioned in the preface section is referred to as “the bodhisattvas,” and this completes the assembly of actually mentioned bodhisattvas.

gsang ba grub pa 'di ni grub snying zhes grags pa'i grub pa'i sde gzhan drug po kun gyi phyi mor grags la/ snying po'i skor gyi bram ze chen po'i do ha ha'i yang phyi mor snang ste/ bde stong sbyor ba'i lhan skyes kyi ye shes bla med kyi rgyud sde kun gyi snying por go ba la shin tu gal che ba rnams so/ / slob dpon sa ra has gsang 'dus kyi gzhung sgos su 'grel ba'i gzhung mdzad pa ni mi snang ngo/ / de nas bdag nyid chen po klu sgrub kyis 'dus pa'i don 'grel pa mdzad de/ de'i lugs kyis ji ltar bkral ba ni 'chad par 'gyur ro/ / slob dpon sgeg pa'i rdo rjes rgyud kyi gleng bzhi'i bshad pa tsam mdzad kyang / rim gnyis kyi lam gyi srol zur pa mi snang ngo/ / sgeg rdor gyi slob ma slob dpon chen po ye shes zhabs la rje btsun 'jam pa'i dbyangs kyis 'dus pa'i don bshad pa'i rim pa la ni ye shes zhabs lugs zhes yongs su grags so/ / de'i lam la rim pa gnyis las bskyed pa'i rim pa ni/ 'jam pa'i rdo rjes gtso mdzad pa'i lha bcu dgu'i dkyil 'khor te bsgrub pa'i thabs kun tu bzang po dang bzhi brgya lnga bcu par bshad pa ltar ro/ / rdzogs pa'i rim pa ni rje btsun gyis gsungs pa'i zhal lung dang / slob dpon nyid kyis mdzad pa'i grol ba'i thig le las 'byung ngo/ /

This Guhyasiddhi is reputed to be the mother text of the other six siddhi collections, which are known as the Essential Collections of the Siddhas.[96] It is also the mother text of Saraha’s Treasury of Songs from the Essential Collections. This is because it is a very important text for understanding the innate exalted wisdom of bliss and emptiness in union, the very essence of all highest yoga tantras. No particular commentary on Guhyasamāja by Ācārya Saraha has appeared. After him the great being Nāgārjuna wrote commentaries on the meaning of Guhyasamāja, and the way that this tradition explains the Guhyasamāja will be described later. Ācārya Lalitavajra[97] explained only the preface to the tantra, and so there is no separate tradition on the paths of the two stages. Lalitavajra’s disciple was the great ācārya Jñānapāda, to whom the meaning of Guhyasamāja was explained by the venerable Mañjuśrī, the stages of which are known as the Jñānapāda tradition. In this path, in the generation stage of the two stages, Mañjuvajra is the principal deity with nineteen deities in the mandala, as is explained in Buddhaśrījñāna’s Samantabhadra Sādhana[98] and in Four Hundred and Fifty Verses.[99] The completion-stage teachings come from Oral Teachings of Mañjuśrī spoken by Mañjuśrī and from Drop of Freedom written by the ācārya himself.

de yang zhal lung las rdzogs rim sgom pa'i thog ma snying khar mi shigs pa'i thig le sgom pa dang / de nas nor bur gsang ba'i thig le sgom pa dbugs dgag pa'i yan lag ces pa srog rtsol gyi yan lag dang / de bsgoms pas gzung ba'i yan lag ces pa 'dzin pa'i yan lag skye ba dang / de nas rjes dran bcu drug sgom pa'i rjes dran gyi yan lag dang / de nas sprul pa'i thig le zhes pa rdo rje'i bzlas pa dang / de nas slar yang snying khar mi shigs pa'i thig le sgom pa lhan cig skyes pa'i ye shes 'ba' zhig gi dbang du byas bsgom par bshad do/ /

Oral Teachings of Mañjuśrī explains in condensed form the first practice of the completion stage as being the meditation on the indestructible drop at the heart, followed by meditation on the secret drop at the vajra jewel. This is known as the branch of stopping the breath and refers to the branch of prāṇāyāma. By meditating on this, the branch of apprehending is generated. This is followed by meditation on the sixteen recollections, which is the branch of recollection. This is followed by the meditation known as emanation drop, which refers to vajra repetition. Then you again meditate on the indestructible drop at the heart this time solely on the basis of innate exalted wisdom.

'dis ni rgyud phyi mar bshad pa'i sbyor ba yan lag drug gi sor bsam gnyis ma bstan par yan lag phyi ma bzhi bshad snang ngo/ / de ltar bshad pa'i shugs kyis sor bsam gnyis bskyed rim du 'jog pa dgongs par snang ste/ ye shes zhabs lugs kyi sbyor drug gi gzhung rnams las kyang sor bsam gnyis bskyed rim du bstan to/ / 'di la rgyud phyi ma las thun mong gi bsnyen pa rdo rje bzhi dang / mchog gi bsnyen pa yan lag drug tu gsungs pa'i don mchog gi bsnyen pa dang bskyed rim gnyis 'gal bar 'dod pa min no/ / rdzogs rim gyi skabs 'dir rgyud phyi ma gzhir byas snang la/ lha mo bzhis zhus dang rdo rje snying po rgyan gyi las kyang btus nas mdzad snang ngo/ / 'di'i rjes 'brang rtsa rgyud kyi bshad pa byed pa rnams kyis rgyud phyi ma ma bshad pa cher mi snang na'ang bshad rgyud gzhan rnams kyis rtsa rgyud 'chad tshul cher mi snang ngo/ / khyad par zhal lung dang grol ba'i thig le gnyis la brten pa'i man ngag gis rtsa rgyud kyi gzhung mang pos rdzogs rim bstan tshul dang / rgyud phyi ma'i sbyor drug gi yan lag phyi ma bzhi zhal lung dang grol ba'i thig le bstun nas legs par 'chad bar 'dug na'ang de ltar bshad pa mi snang ngo ; ;

It can be seen that this work explains the last four of the six-branch yoga taught in the Later Tantra, leaving out the two branches of individual withdrawal and meditative absorption. From this explanation it is clear that he intends the branches of individual withdrawal and meditative absorption to be included in the generation stage, and the works of the Jñānapāda tradition on the six-branch yoga do teach individual withdrawal and meditative absorption as being generation-stage practices. For this tradition, the statement from the Later Tantra that the ordinary approach practice is the four vajras and the supreme approach practice is the six-branch yoga does not mean that the supreme approach practice and the generation stage are mutually exclusive. [25] In the section on the completion stage this work takes the Later Tantra as its basis and also draws on the Tantra Requested by the Four Goddesses and the Ornament of Vajra Essence Tantra. Of the followers of this tradition who have explained the Root Tantra, there are not many who do not explain the Later Tantra. However, there are not many explanations of the Root Tantra by way of the other explanatory tantras. In particular, the core teachings that arise from Oral Teachings and Drop of Freedom show how several passages from the Root Tantra teach the completion stage, but this is not explained by these followers. Moreover the last four branches of the six-branch yoga of the Later Tantra can be suitably explained to accord with Oral Teachings and Drop of Freedom, but this is also not done.

slob dpon kun dga' snying pos bshad tshul la phra rags kyis bsgyur ba'i 'dus pa'i 'grel pa chen mo 'dis mdzad par byas pa ni 'grel pa de nyid la ma brtags par smra bar 'dug pas mi 'thad la/ lo chen gyis bsgyur ba'i 'grel pa kun snying gis mdzad par byas pa ni/ slob dpon dri med sbas pa'i 'grel par yang de'i le'u lnga pa'i bshad pa bkod cing khungs ma yin no/ / 'dis ni las rgya bsten par bshad pa thams cad khyab 'jug gi rgyud kyi rjes su 'brang ba 'dod yon gyi yul spong mi nus pa'i chags can re shig drang ba'i phyir du gsungs pa tsam gyi don dang / bshad gci sogs kyi bza' ba'i dam tshig bsten par gsungs pa thams cad kyang phra men ma dang 'chol ba'i rgyud la zhugs pa rnams kyi ngor mdzad pa tsam du bshad nas/ gdul bya rab kyi dbang du byas nas de dag bshad pa min par bshad la/ nang gi rtsa rlung gi thig le sgom pa sogs kyi rnal 'byor gzhan nas rdzogs rim du bshad pa'i rigs kyang ma bshad do/ / de rnams la bsams nas bod kyi bla ma rnams kyis kun snying gis gsang 'dus yo gar bkral zhes gsung ngo/ / 'di ni rgya gar ba'i chen po gzhan du mas bshad pa dang mi mthun pa'i bla med kyi rgyud kyi bshad srol du snang ngo/ /

Concerning the explanations of Ānandagarbha, ascribing the Great Commentary on Guhyasamāja translated by Trarak as being by this master is the statement of someone who has not examined this commentary and is therefore not valid. Concerning the commentary attributed to Ānandagarbha and translated by the great Lotsāwa Rinchen Sangpo, an explanation of its fifth chapter is to be found in the Vimalagupta commentary and is a valid reference.[100] In this work it says that all descriptions concerning the use of a karma consort are only for gathering those followers of Viṣṇu tantras, who are desire-driven practitioners that cannot abandon the pleasures of the senses; that all statements on commitment to the pledge of eating and drinking excrement and urine and so on were only made for those who engaged in demonic and perverse tantras; and that all these statements were not made for the sake of the best disciples. Also, Ānandagarbha does not talk about meditation on the inner channels, winds, and drops, and so on, which elsewhere are described as belonging to the completion stage. All this has led Tibetan masters to conclude that “Ānandagarbha commented on Guhyasamāja as yoga tantra.” This way of explaining highest yoga tantra is at odds with the explanations of many great Indian masters.

slob dpon shAnita pas rtsa rgyud kyi le'u dang pos thabs las byung ba'i 'bras bu'i rgyus bstan/ de thob par byed pa'i thabs rgyud la bzhi yod par lhag ma le'u bcu drug gis 'chad de/ gsum ldan gyi le'u bzhis bsnyen pa dang / gnyis ldan gyi le'u bzhis nyer sgrub dang / rdzogs ldan gyi le'u bzhis sgrub pa dang / dga' ba can gyi le'u bzhis sgrub pa chen po bstan la/ rgyud phyi ma ni de rnams gsal bar byed pa'o zhes 'chad do/ / 'dis rim pa dang po la mi bskyod pas gtso byas pa'i lha bcu dgu dang / bskyed rim brtan pa'i 'og tu sgom pa'i rdzogs rim yan lag drug gyi tshul ni ye shes zhabs lugs dang 'phags lugs dang dus 'khor gyi lugs gang dang yang mi 'dra ba cig rgyud phyi ma la brten nas le'u bdun pa'i don du 'chad do/ /
de dag las gzhan pa'i 'grel byed rnams ni ye shes zhabs kyi rjes su 'brangs nas 'chad par snang la/ re re tsam de'i rjes su 'brangs pa'i gsal kha mi snang yang bshad pa'i 'gangs chung bar snang bas ma bris so/ / de ltar na dang dpal 'dus pa'i rgyud 'grel pa la shing rta chen po'i srol ni 'phags lugs dang ye shes zhabs lugs gnyis su grags pa ltar shes par bya'o/ /

Ācārya Śāntipa explains[101] that the first chapter of the Root Tantra teaches the tantra of “the result that arises from the method,” and that there are four tantras of “method to achieve that result,” which are explained by the remaining sixteen chapters. Four tretā chapters teach the branch of approach. Four dvāpara chapters teach the branch of close accomplishment. Four catur chapters teach the branch of accomplishment. And four joy chapters teach the branch of great accomplishment.[102] These are clarified by the eighteenth chapter. For the generation stage he describes nineteen deities, with Akṣobhya as the main deity. His explanation of the way to meditate on the six branches of the completion stage after the solid grounding of the generation stage differs from that of the Ārya, the Jñānapāda, and the Kālacakra traditions. [26] Based on the explanations of the eighteenth chapter, he says that these stages are the intent of chapter 7.
Commentators other than the above appear to follow Jñānapāda in their explanations. There may be one or two in whose works it is not clear whether they follow Jñānapāda or not, but as their writings are not greatly significant, they will not be discussed here. Therefore the pioneers of the glorious Guhyasamāja Tantra commentarial tradition are the Ārya tradition and the Jñānapāda tradition.
